review.title: When do Numbers Really Matter?
review.abstract: Common wisdom has it that small distinctions in the probabilities (parameters) quantifying a belief network do not matter much for the results of probabilistic queries. Yet, one can develop realistic scenarios under which small variations in network parameters can lead to significant changes in computed queries. A pending theoretical question is then to analytically characterize parameter changes that do or do not matter. In this paper, we study the sensitivity of probabilistic queries to changes in network parameters and prove some tight bounds on the impact that such parameters can have on queries. Our analytic results pinpoint some interesting situations under which parameter changes do or do not matter. These results are important for knowledge engineers as they help them identify influential network parameters. They also help explain some of the previous experimental results and observations with regards to network robustness against parameter changes.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: A belief network is a compact representation of a probability distribution (Pearl, 1988; Jensen, 2001). It consists of two parts, one qualitative and another quantitative. The qualitative part of a belief network is a set of conditional probability tables (CPTs) that quantitatively capture our beliefs in such influences. sections.heading: 4. Changes that (Don’t) Matter
sections.text: We now return to a central question: When are changes in network parameters important and when not? As we have already mentioned, there are experimental studies that examine the robustness of faith networks to parameter changes (Pradhan et al., 1996), but we have also shown very simple and intuitive examples in which networks can be very sensitive to small parameter changes, which requires a better understanding of the effects of parameter changes on queries, so that one can intuitively sort out situations in which such changes matter or do not matter. Our goal in this section is to further develop such an understanding by examining some of the implications of theorem 3.3. First, we highlight the difference between this theorem and previous sensitivity analysis results.

sections.heading: 4.1 Network-Specific Sensitivity Analysis
sections.text: One of the main differences between our results and other approaches to sensitivity analysis is that we do not need to know the faith network and therefore do not need to draw any conclusions. sections.heading: 4.2 Assuring Query Robustness
sections.text: One of the important questions that we still have to clarify is: "What does it mean for a parameter change that it does not matter?" One can imagine at least three definitions: First, the absolute change in probability Pr (y | e) is small. Second, the relative change in probabilities Pr (y | e) is small. Third, the relative change in probabilities O (y | e) is small. The first idea is the most widely used in the literature, so we will assume it for the rest of this section that we have a faith network for a diagnostic application and assume that we care about the robustness of the query Pr (y | e) in relation to changes in network parameters. In this application, y is a certain disease that predicts the disease, with Pr (y | e) =.9 Let us define robustness in this case to be an absolute change in the given query.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: Based on this technique, we have experimented with some faith networks, only to find that these networks are more sensitive to parameter changes than previous experimental studies suggest. This observation leads us to an analytical study of the effect of parameter changes, with the aim of characterizing situations in which parameter changes do not matter or do not matter. We have reported on a number of results in this direction. Our central finding shows that faith networks are robust in a very specific sense: the relative change in query odds is limited by the relative change in parameter rates. A closer look at this result, its significance and its impact provides interesting characterizations of parameter changes that matter or do not matter, and analytically explains some of the earlier experimental results and observations on the subject.
